ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Analysis of golden age literature
I developed a deep insight into, perhaps, the crux of Spanish literature, as well as frameworks for literary critical theory.
More insight on text analyzation, particularly when it comes to literature, as the title would suggest. That said, this obviously helps in all realms of writing, and beyond.
I learned so much from a deep engagement with Cervantesthe literary theory alongside was also so great.
Reading and analytical skills, lots of social context on Spanish Baroque and golden eras
I improved my conversational Spanish, and learned to critically analyze Don Quixote.

I learned the impact of Cervantess novel, a few themes and literary devices it employs, and the novels historical context. I also learned about Cervantes as a man, and got to practice my Spanish. Having graduate students in the class also helped undergrads get a sense for what graduate work in Spanish looks like and how graduate students analyze texts, which was very impressive.
I read all of Don Quijote in the original Spanish.
I learned about the Spanish literary tradition and got to read and discuss a book in Spanish which helped me with my conversational skills.
Literature close-reading in Spanish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think it would make a better lecture than seminar

Perhaps the book can be split into smaller chunks by assigning readings for the first weeks of the semester when there were none. Additional critical essays relevant to a week's assigned reading could also further class discussions.
I think that the course was well in that we were free to discuss things as we pleased. Everyones ideas always seemed to collectively add up and generate a lot of great dialogue.

Strengths: the book is great. The reading list is good, and there is an appropriate amount of reaidng to do each week.

WEaknesses: discussion felt stagnant and even trivial, despite an incredibly smart group of students.
Breaks up reading well, set up for lots of discussion
This course gave me ample opportunity to improve my Spanish. It was very difficult to read Quixote in Spanish, but the teacher gave us many resources.

I loved the novel and I loved prof. Jones. Would have loved a bit more structure and grade transparency. I have no idea what my grade is/will be, and there were only two assignments the entire semester, so theres very little opportunities for movement.
I enjoyed the discussions and learning from Professor Jones. The class was very engaging and the activities were productive.

The class was very interesting and we looked at archival sources from the Beinecke and visited the Yuag! It was seminar style and Prof. Jones was very engaging and brought in a lot of external context.

The strength of this course is that you get to read one of the greatest works in Spanish literature and connect to different global contexts. However, the class conversations are lacking and the lack of organization means that you really have to keep up with the readings on your own.
Class discussions could be improved

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the course is very good. Professor Jones is always a joy to have. It was near (as an undergrad) to have grad students in the class, because of the other perspective that they had and could share.
I would, with the caveat that you get out as much as you put in
Yes! You gain lots of cultural knowledge and its a great experience and accomplishment to read the whole novel
I would, because you learn to analyze Don Quixote from a historical and literature perspective.

I would, but you have to be deliberate about doing your readings and making sure you know what will be on the midterm. There is very little incentive to read unless youre very interested in the novel, and the midterm has a bunch of things that you have to look up on your own.
Yes! Everyone should read El Quixote and learn from Professor Jones. The class were very fruitful and inspiring.
Yes, this class was very interesting and engaging - especially good to practice Spanish and improve conversational skills.
Yes, but only to read Don Quijote
No
